    Download Hi-Res ImageDownload to MS-PowerPointCite This:J. Med. Chem. 2021, 64, 8, 5001-5017

    RETURN TO ISSUEPREVArticleNEXT

    Prodrugs of a 1′-CN-4-Aza-7,9-dideazaadenosine C-Nucleoside Leading to the Discovery of Remdesivir (GS-5734) as a Potent Inhibitor of Respiratory Syncytial Virus with Efficacy in the African Green Monkey Model of RSV

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    A discovery program targeting respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) identified C-nucleoside 4 (RSV A2 EC50 = 530 nM) as a phenotypic screening lead targeting the RSV RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp). Prodrug exploration resulted in the discovery of remdesivir (1, GS-5734) that is >30-fold more potent than 4 against RSV in HEp-2 and NHBE cells. Metabolism studies in vitro confirmed the rapid formation of the active triphosphate metabolite, 1-NTP, and in vivo studies in cynomolgus and African Green monkeys demonstrated a >10-fold higher lung tissue concentration of 1-NTP following molar normalized IV dosing of 1 compared to that of 4. A once daily 10 mg/kg IV administration of 1 in an African Green monkey RSV model demonstrated a >2-log10 reduction in the peak lung viral load. These early data following the discovery of 1 supported its potential as a novel treatment for RSV prior to its development for Ebola and approval for COVID-19 treatment.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Acute respiratory viruses such as respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), influenza, and rhinovirus are significant global health problems. Year round, these viruses circulate in the global population and are most prevalent during the winter months in each hemisphere.(1,2) In vulnerable patient populations, they can have lethal consequences and the economic burden is considerable, with estimated costs in the United States exceeding $40B for rhinovirus and $87B for influenza. Some influenza viruses that have efficient human-to-human transmission also carry the additional risk of evolving into pandemics. Notable historical examples include the 1918 Spanish Flu and the more recent 2009 H1N1 swine flu pandemic.(3) The emergence of the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 in late 2019 has resulted in the most recent global pandemic and has once again thrown respiratory viruses to the forefront of public awareness. A short 9 months after the WHO designated COVID-19 a pandemic, there are upwards of 100M confirmed infections and more than 2.3M recorded deaths worldwide.(4) Research into the prevention and treatment of acute respiratory viruses is therefore of critical importance.
    Remdesivir (1, GS-5734, Veklury) is the first agent to be approved as a treatment for hospitalized COVID-19 patients (Figure 1).(5) The rapid approval of 1 for COVID-19 was enabled by extensive research conducted since its initial discovery as part of a program to identify new treatments for RSV.(6) Following the identification of potent anti-Ebola virus activity of 1 in vitro and in vivo at the start of the West Africa Ebola outbreak, it was selected for clinical development as a potential treatment option for Ebola.(7,8) The development of 1 provided a platform of clinical experience and drug supply from which to rapidly launch clinical studies investigating its efficacy for COVID-19 leading to its regulatory approval.(9,10)
    RSV infection, despite its efficient human-to-human transmission, generally results in mild disease that resolves without complications in most immunocompetent patients. However, progression to the lower respiratory tract can lead to airway inflammation, symptoms of bronchiolitis, pneumonia, and, in some cases, respiratory failure. These outcomes are commonly associated with vulnerable patient populations including infants, the elderly with underlying comorbidities, and immunocompromised individuals.(11−18) In infants less than 1 year of age, RSV is associated with significantly more deaths than influenza and a greater risk for the long-term development of recurrent wheezing and asthma in children.(11−13) Elderly individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder, asthma, and diabetes mellitus are also a known high-risk population for severe RSV infection.(14−17) Another patient population susceptible to RSV infection is post-transplant patients, in which severe lower respiratory tract infection leads to greater morbidity and mortality.(18) The only treatment options for RSV are palivizumab, approved for prophylaxis in infants, and the broad-spectrum antiviral ribavirin (2) that has limited efficacy and carries significant safety concerns for caregivers.(19−21)
    RSV is a negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus from the pneumoviridae family.(22) The antisense positive-strand RNA encodes for 11 viral proteins, and in recent years, significant progress has been made to demonstrate clinical proof-of-concept for targeting some of these viral proteins. The fusion inhibitors presatovir, rilematovir, and sisunatovir, in addition to a next-generation RSV nucleocapsid inhibitor EDP-938 and the nucleoside analogue lumicitabine (3), have all demonstrated efficacy in human RSV challenge studies.(23−27) Nucleoside 3 targets the RSV RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), which is a large 250 kDa protein that functions within a complex with other RSV proteins, e.g., P and M2-1.(22) The RdRp has the critical function of copying the viral RNA, and like many other viral RdRp, its function can be inhibited by nucleoside analogues that mimic the natural RNA substrates.(28)
    Our interest in RSV has been long-standing given the unmet medical need for safer and more effective treatments for RSV. In 2008, we initiated a program aimed at discovering novel treatments for RSV infection. The leads for our discovery program were identified through phenotypic screening campaigns, the first, a high-throughput screen of small-molecule library comprising ∼400 K compounds and the second, a medium-throughput screen of riboside nucleosides and nucleotides. The phenotypic screen assessed the inhibition of RSV A2-induced cytopathic effects in the cervical adenocarcinoma HEp-2 cell line. In the ∼400 k compound screen, a submicromolar RSV fusion lead was identified, which was subsequently optimized into the clinical fusion inhibitor presatovir, GS-5806.(29) The nucleoside screen identified 4, which targets the RSV RdRp and therefore has an orthogonal mechanism of action to the fusion inhibitor. Fusion inhibitors prevent the spread of RSV by blocking viral entry into uninfected cells, whereas the nucleoside analogues inhibit the viral RNA replication process in cells that harbor the virus. Given the difference in mechanisms of action, we elected to optimize 4 in parallel to the fusion leads.
    Nucleoside 4 was first prepared in a HCV RdRp program that led to the clinical candidate 5.(30−32) Indeed, the expansive collections of HCV RdRp nucleoside inhibitors within the broader research community also resulted in other groups discovering RSV inhibitors based on leads from their HCV programs, e.g., 3.(33,34) Despite the significant efforts toward identifying HCV RdRp inhibitors across many research groups, 6 was the only FDA-approved nucleoside analogue that emerged, illustrating that the successful development of potent and selective nucleoside inhibitors for HCV RdRp was very challenging.(35) Aside from 2, all of the clinically advanced RdRp inhibitors in Figure 1 retain the 3′-OH and either a 2′-OH or 2′-F group to satisfy a key recognition element for viral RNA polymerase binding. Their nucleoside triphosphates (NTPs), e.g., 1-NTP, are generated inside infected cells and compete with the natural nucleotides as substrates for incorporation by the viral polymerase into nascent viral RNA strands. Once incorporated, the modified nucleoside can result in immediate or delayed chain termination of viral RNA strand synthesis due to the structural modifications around the ribose core, e.g., 1′-CN, 2′-C-Me, or 4′-CH2Cl.(7,36−38) For example, the 1′-CN modification following incorporation allows several additional nucleotides to be incorporated before halting the RNA synthesis, potentially as a result of steric factors hindering the polymerase motion along the RNA or subtle changes in the tertiary structure of the double-strand RNA.(7,38) Another structural feature of several compounds in Figure 1 is the application of ester prodrugs to mask one or more of the hydroxyl groups and/or 5′-phosphoramidate prodrugs that can more efficiently generate the intermediate monophosphate metabolite precursor of the NTP inside cells.(39)
    Here, we describe in detail the follow-up efforts on RSV screening lead 4, including the SAR of 1′-modifications that established that the 1′-CN group was optimal for RSV potency and viral polymerase selectivity. Prodrugs were designed to either improve oral absorption or optimize cellular potency, which led to the discovery of the 5′-2-ethylbutylalanine monophenol phosphoramidate, 1, as a more potent RSV inhibitor with efficacy in the African Green monkey RSV model. In recent years, the broad-spectrum in vitro and in vivo antiviral efficacies of 1 toward multiple respiratory virus pathogens including, Nipah, MERS, SARS-CoV, and, more recently, SARS-CoV-2 have been demonstrated.(40−44) The early data reported here on the discovery of 1 for RSV supports the continued investigation of 1 beyond its approval for SARS-CoV-2 treatment toward other respiratory viruses, including RSV.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The synthesis of the 1′-CN C-nucleoside analogue 4 has been described previously.(7,31) Analogues 7–10 (Scheme 1) that are structurally close to 4 were also assessed from the library to evaluate the SAR around the 1′-modification. The synthesis of 7–10 has been previously reported, along with the synthesis of their respective NTPs.(6,8,30−32) The submicromolar RSV potency of nucleoside 4 in the initial HEp-2 screening assay was striking since it was 8-fold more potent toward RSV than toward the HCV 1b replicon (Table 1). Earlier work had shown that the SAR for the 1′-modifications toward HCV was narrow, declining precipitously with larger substituents.(30) A similar trend was observed for RSV, indicating that this trajectory has limited substitution scope for RSV.
    Table 1. RSV and HCV Antiviral Activities of 1′-Modified C-Nucleoside Analogues
    cpd.1′2′RSV RNPa IC50 (μM)HCV RdRpb IC50 (μM)RSV A2 HEp-2 EC50/CC50 (μM)HCV 1b Huh-7 EC50/CC50 (μM)MT-4 CC50 (μM)
    4CNH1.1c5.6c0.53/>1004.1/>89>50
    7HH  >50/0.0360.0035/0.15<0.01
    8MeH1.5205.5/9339/>454.5
    9C≡CHH3.023234/>100>89/>89>50
    10CNMe38d0.37>100/>100>89/>89>200
    a

    IC50 values are determined using the NTP analogue in a cell-free RSV ribonucleoprotein (RNP) complex assay.

    b

    IC50 values are determined using the NTP analogue in a cell-free HCV RdRp assay.

    c

    1 and 4 generate the same metabolite, 1-NTP.

    d

    n = 1 data. All data are n ≥ 2 replicates unless noted.

    To establish that the antiviral activity was driven by the respective triphosphate metabolite, the RSV ribonucleoprotein (RNP) complex containing the RdRp was isolated from RSV-infected cell extracts and a biochemical assay was established.(7) Triphosphate 1-NTP was found to be 5-fold more potent toward the RSV RNP complex than recombinant HCV RdRp.(31) Screening of the 1′-methyl 8, 1′-ethynyl 9, and the 1′-CN, 2′-C-Me 10C-nucleosides resulted in a progressively reduced anti-RSV activity that was consistent with the decreased inhibition of their respective NTPs toward the RSV RNP complex. The same trend of decreasing antiviral potency was observed for 8 and 9 toward HCV, which was also in line with the decreased inhibition of the triphosphates toward HCV RdRp. However, the 1′-CN, 2′-C-Me analogue 10 was an exception since despite lacking HCV activity in cells, its triphosphate was 15-fold more potent toward the HCV RdRp than 1-NTP. It was known that the 2′-C-Me modification is a potency driver toward HCV RdRp and is present in many of the most effective HCV RdRp inhibitors, as exemplified by 5 and 6 in Figure 1.(45) Structural modeling of the RSV and HCV RdRp active sites suggested that the reduced potency of 10 toward RSV RdRp was likely due to residue E778 that occludes the RSV active site in the proximity of the 2′-β position of the ribose.(8) In HCV RdRp, this region is occupied by the smaller and more accommodating S282 residue. The 1′-unsubstituted C-nucleoside analogue 7 was found to be cytotoxic across multiple cell lines, including the rapidly proliferating MT-4 human T-cells. Taken together, these data established that the 1′-CN group was optimal among several 1′-modifications on the adenine C-nucleoside for RSV potency and selectivity. Inspired by 4, the SAR was later expanded beyond the 1′-modifications leading to the first report of potent 4′-modified C-nucleosides toward RSV.(46)
    Table 2. In Vitro and In Vivo Profiles of Esters 11–14
    cpd.5′-ester2′, 3′-estersRSV HEp-2 EC50/CC50 (μM)log DCaco-2 AB/BA (10 × 10–6 cm–1)F%a rat/dog/cyno
    4HH0.53/>100<0.30.17/2.112/89/3.4
    11acetylacetyl0.82/>1001.70.9/1.9 
    12propionylpropionyl0.43/>1002.7<0.1/0.26b 
    13iso-butyryliso-butyryl0.26/813.62.1/1.557c/-/28c
    14valineH1.11/>1000.50.55/0.45 
    a

    n = 3 animals.

    b

    Caco-2 compound recovery is low.

    c

    F% of compound 4 based on the mg equivalent of 4 administered as the prodrug, standard deviation ±3% for rat and ±9% for cyno. All in vitro data are n ≥ 2 replicates unless noted.

    Compound 4 has a low log D and demonstrated low cell permeability in the Caco-2 assay with an efflux ratio (BA/AB) of 12 (Table 2). It was therefore not surprising that the oral bioavailability was low in cynomolgus monkey and rat. In dogs, the oral bioavailability was high, which is thought to be due to the larger pore size and greater pore frequency in the paracellular pathway of the dog and potentially the role of nucleoside transporters specific to the dog.(47) Riboside inhibitors frequently employ ester prodrugs to mask one or more of the ribose hydroxyl groups and improve oral bioavailability. For example, the iso-butyryl esters masking both free hydroxyls in 3 were reported to improve the oral bioavailability of the parent nucleoside in cynomolgus monkeys from 3 to 44%.(33) A similar tactic was attempted on 4 through the preparation of ester prodrugs 11–14 that would be expected to provide the greatest absorption benefit by masking all of the polar ribose hydroxyls or by leveraging peptide transporters, e.g., 14, modeled after oral valganciclovir.(48) The ester analogues were readily prepared using a straightforward carbodiimide coupling followed by deprotection of the amino acid protecting group in example 14 (Scheme 1).
    The most effective ester prodrug was the highly lipophilic tri-iso-butyryl ester 13, which demonstrated 2-fold improved potency, a higher log D, and the greatest improvement in Caco-2 permeability with no efflux (Table 2). Following oral dosing of 13, no ester prodrug was detected in the plasma due to rapid pre-systemic cleavage of the esters, but the systemic exposure of 4 was increased by ∼5- and ∼8-fold in rat and cynomolgus monkey, respectively, suggesting that this may be a promising approach to increase the oral delivery of 4. Recently, a deutero analogue of 13 has been reported to have a 57% oral bioavailability in rats consistent with these data.(49) Despite these results, the modest improvement in antiviral activity for 13 implied that permeability was not limiting the antiviral potency of 4 in cell culture.
    The first step in intracellular anabolism of a nucleoside analogue to the corresponding monophosphate can be rate-limiting leading to reduced potency in cellular assays. To avoid this limitation, monophosphate prodrugs, e.g., 5 and 6, are frequently employed to bypass this anabolism step and deliver higher concentrations of the monophosphate species inside cells.(32,35) A variety of 5′-monophosphate prodrugs were designed on 4 to assess whether more potent inhibition of RSV in cell culture could be obtained. Phosphate prodrugs screened included the thioester prodrug 15,(31) phosphordiamide esters 16a−b, and monoalanine phosphoramidate esters 18a–k and 19 (Scheme 2).
    The thioester prodrug 15 was prepared using the phosphorane reagent described by Lefebvre et al.(50) The syntheses of prodrugs 16a−b, 18a–k, and 19 have been described previously except 18c, 18h, and 18k.(8) Monoamidate 18c was prepared in moderate yield by direct coupling of the amidate reagent in the presence of MgCl2 to nucleoside 4. A higher yielding and more robust procedure that coupled the desired amidate reagent to the 2′,3′-acetonide protected nucleoside 17, followed by removal of the acetonide, was also developed.(8) For example, monoamidate 18k was prepared in a 62% overall yield from the protected nucleoside 17. The diastereomeric monoamidate mixture 18j was separated by chiral chromatography to afford 1 and 1-Rp. Later, a stereospecific synthesis was developed and the two diastereoisomers were assigned by determination of the small-molecule X-ray structure of the more potent isomer 1.(8,51)
    More substantial potency gains were realized with 5′-phosphate prodrugs that bypass the first phosphorylation step in the conversion of 4 to its intermediate 5′-monophosphate in cells and thereby enhance the formation of 1-NTP (Table 3). The dithioester phosphate prodrug 15 was earlier found to improve the activity of 4 toward HCV in hepatic Huh-7 cells, confirming that, at least in hepatic cells, there is evidence for inefficient metabolism of 4 to its monophosphate.(31) However, in the HEp-2 cell RSV assay, 15 demonstrated only a small improvement in RSV potency and a relatively low selectivity index. The prodrug following thioester cleavage releases an episulfide, which may be the root cause for the reduced selectivity.(52) Phosphoramidate-based prodrugs were also evaluated including the phosphordiamide esters 16a−b and monoalanine phosphoramidate esters 18a–k (Table 3). The potency advance was achieved using the monoalanine phosphoramidate ester prodrug approach, which generates the monophosphate in cells via the mechanism described in Figure 2.(39,53) Initial cleavage of the alanine ester by intracellular esterases, e.g., carboxyesterase 1, carboxyesterase 2, or cathepsin A, is followed by intramolecular cyclization and ejection of the phenol-leaving group. The cyclic intermediate is then hydrolyzed to the intermediate alanine monophosphate (alanine metabolite) followed by the P–N bond cleavage by histidine triad enzymes, e.g., Hint1. This process leads to the intracellular generation of the monophosphate metabolite, effectively bypassing the slow first phosphorylation step in the intracellular metabolism of 4 and ultimately formation of 1-NTP.
    The diastereomeric isopropylmonoamidate ester mixture (18b mixture) was prepared given the precedence for the Sp isomer of this amidate prodrug in tenofovir alafenamide. The mixture demonstrated no improvement in activity over 4 (data not shown), and the single Sp diastereomer 18b provided a modest improvement over 4 (Table 3). It was hypothesized that the moderately high polarity (log D = 1.1) of the iso-propyl amidate prodrug may limit cell permeability and disfavor binding in the esterase cleavage pocket, similar to the commonly accepted relationship observed for polar compounds disfavoring binding to P450 metabolic enzymes. The more lipophilic 2-ethylbutyl ester 18j was subsequently prepared to increase the log D while avoiding the introduction of additional stereochemistry or steric hinderance from α-carbon branching. We were delighted to find a 20-fold improvement in RSV potency for 18j relative to 4. Moreover, the same prodrug on the 1′-ethynyl nucleoside, 19, also substantially improved the antiviral activity by >30-fold compared to parent 9, implying that the 1′-modified C-nucleosides, in general, have inefficient metabolism to the monophosphate precursor. Encouraged by the potency improvement of 18j, the prodrug ester SAR was explored across a range of lipophilicity to identify the optimal ester prodrug. Ethyl ester 18a, which also has a low log D but lacks α-branching, was less potent than 18j, suggesting that the increased lipophilicity of the 2-ethylbutyl ester, as opposed to the lack of α-branching, was the main driver for the improved potency. In general, for esters that lacked α-branching, as lipophilicity was increased, e.g., 18c, 18h, 18i, and 18j, the RSV HEp-2 potency was improved by more than 10-fold compared to 4. When α-branching was present, higher lipophilicity or strained small rings were required to improve the potency, e.g., cyclooctyl 18k and cyclobutyl 18e. Following the chiral separation of the 18j isomers, the Sp isomer 1 was found to be more potent than 1-Rp, resulting in an overall 35-fold improvement in potency relative to the parent 4 (Table 3). The assignment of Sp stereochemistry in 1 was later determined by solving the single-crystal X-ray structure and is consistent with the stereochemistry for tenofovir alafenamide and sofosbuvir 6.(7,35,51,54) The judicious choice of the ester moiety in generating optimal potency in the phosphoramidate analogues strongly suggests that the rate-limiting step in the prodrug breakdown is the initial ester cleavage, as described in Figure 2. Phosphordiamide prodrugs were also evaluated, e.g., 16a,b, and found to be less potent than 1. It is presumed that the metabolic process for the phosphordiamide prodrugs is analogous to the monoamidates, with initial ester cleavage of one amino acid ester, followed by cyclization onto the phosphorus and ejection of the other amino acid moiety (essentially acting as a surrogate of the phenol). Lipophilicity appeared equally important for optimal potency in the phosphordiamide analogues since the 2-ethylbutylalanine phosphordiamide 16b was more potent than the corresponding ethyl ester analogue 16a. This suggests that the intracellular esterases that initiate the prodrug breakdown may be the same for both the monoamidate and phosphordiamide prodrugs of 4.
    Table 3. Phosphate Prodrug Antiviral Activity in HEp-2 and NHBE Cells
    cpd.1′alanine esterRSV HEp-2 EC50/CC50 (μM)HEp-2 SIaRSV NHBE EC50 (μM)log D
    4CN 0.53/>100>1891.85<0.3
    15CN 0.15/8.7b58  
    16aCNethyl6.48/>100c>15 <0.3
    16bCN2-ethylbutyl0.31/361160.172.7
    18aCNethyl0.30/>73>2430.850.6
    18bCNiso-propyl (Sp)0.36/>100>2772.501.1
    18cCNCH2cpropyl0.044/5011360.621.5
    18dCNt-butyl4.50/>100>22>5.01.7
    18eCNcbutyl0.075/344530.421.7
    18fdCNcpentyl0.17/>804710.351.8
    18gCN3-pentyl0.31/>100323>5.02.0
    18hCNCH2cbutyl0.024/239580.132.0
    18idCNneopentyl0.050/112200.532.1
    18jCN2-ethylbutyl0.027/9.23410.0692.5
    1CN2-ethylbutyl (Sp)0.015/6.14070.0492.4

    a

    SI, selectivity index (CC50/EC50).

    b

    96-well assay format.

    c

    n = 1.

    d

    Single undefined isomer. All data n ≥ 2 unless noted. All compounds are mixtures of Sp and Rp isomers unless noted otherwise. c, cyclo.

    With RSV as the target virus of interest, it was important to also ensure in vitro potency of the optimized prodrugs against RSV in a primary human lung epithelial cell line. To this end, RSV assays were developed in normal human bronchial epithelial cells (NHBEs) and human airway epithelial (HAE) cell cultures derived from human lung donor tissue.(55) Screening of the prodrugs in the NHBE cells established that the SAR trends were generally similar and the 2-ethylbutylalanine ester 1 was the most potent with 38-fold improved activity over parent 4 (Table 3). Detection of secreted RSV in HAE culture supernatant further demonstrated that an ∼40-fold increase in the concentration of 4 is required to achieve a similar viral load drop as 1 and its diastereoisomer 1-Rp (Figure 3). The reduction in RSV levels in the HAE culture supernatants is comparable at all concentrations of 1 and 1-Rp (see the Supporting Information). Incubation of 1 and 1-Rp, at 0.25 μM in the HAE cells, resulted in a median viral load drop of 2.50 and 3.84 log10, respectively, when compared to that of 4. The cumulative data in NHBE and HAE cells supported the potential of the phosphoramidate prodrug 1 to effectively inhibit RSV in lung cells in vivo.
    In vitro metabolism studies were conducted to assess intracellular 1-NTP formation (Figure 4) in HEp-2 cells, NHBE cells, and HAE cultures to confirm that the antiviral potency was correlated with 1-NTP formation. In HEp-2 cells, the 1-NTP levels increased in proportion with the increase in the incubation concentration from 1 to 10 μM (Figure 4, panel A). The single diastereoisomer 1 and its isomeric mixture 18j yielded similar levels of 1-NTP, although it was marginally lower for 18j at the elevated incubation concentration. The iso-propyl prodrug 18b was also tested at the high concentration in HEp-2 cells and found to generate low levels of 1-NTP consistent with its weaker antiviral activity (data not shown). The average 1-NTP levels from continuous incubations of 1 and parent 4 at 1 μM over 48 h (Figure 4, panels A–C) were calculated for each cell type and are shown in Table 4. In all cases, higher concentrations of 1-NTP were generated from 1 consistent with its improved antiviral activity in these cells relative to 4. Taken together, these data confirm that 4 has slow and inefficient metabolism in a variety of human cell types, including primary lung epithelial cells, and the phosphoramidate prodrug 1 effectively bypasses this metabolic limitation to generate high concentrations of 1-NTP and improve potency.
    Table 4. In Vitro RSV Antiviral Activity and Metabolism
    cpd.cellRSV EC50(μM)avg. [1-NTP]apmol/106cellsintracellular IC50b(μM)
    1HEp-20.01522.00.11
     NHBE0.04920.50.14
     HAE 6.54 
    4HEp-20.532.00.35
     NHBE1.850.90.22
     HAE 1.1 
    a

    Average 1-NTP concentrations following a continuous 1 μM incubation over 48 h.

    b

    Estimated 1-NTP concentrations in cells at EC50 concentrations (intracellular IC50) calculated using average cell volumes of 3 pL/cell (HEp-2) and 7 pL/cell (NHBE).

    The intracellular 1-NTP assessment can also be used to estimate the average intracellular concentration of 1-NTP that is present in cells when 50% of the virus replication is inhibited (intracellular IC50) effectively mirroring the biochemical IC50 experiment. The calculated intracellular IC50 from the average concentration of 1-NTP is reported in Table 4 and results in an RSV RdRp intracellular IC50 ranging from 0.11 to 0.35 μM, several fold more potent than the biochemical assay IC50 reported in Table 1 but within a comparable range.
    In vivo, 1 was expected to be rapidly cleared from systemic circulation due to the abundance of hepatic esterases that would result in rapid hepatic clearance. The human pharmacokinetics for 1 following intravenous injection have since confirmed a rapid clearance of the prodrug.(56) The plasma Cmax of 1 following the 75 mg human dose delivered by IV over 30 min was approximately 5 μM and fell rapidly, in the first 1 h, to below 1 μM. To reflect the reduced exposure of 1 in vivo, a 2 h pulse incubation (drug-containing media replaced with fresh incubation media) was conducted in NHBE cells (Figure 4B). Following media replacement, concentrations of 1-NTP derived from 1 remained higher than those from 4 over the 48 hour incubation due to the long intracellular half-life of the 1-NTP metabolite. High antiviral potency coupled with the in vitro metabolism data in primary lung cells supported the progression of 1 into in vivo studies.
    To the best of our knowledge, at the time of these studies, no data existed that demonstrated the ability of phosphoramidate nucleoside prodrugs to effectively produce nucleoside triphosphate within lung tissues from exposure in the central compartment. The mechanism of breakdown for the phosphoramidate prodrug described in Figure 2 is proposed to begin with an esterase cleavage mediated by cathepsin A or carboxyesterases. This metabolic process is very efficient in hepatocytes due to the high expression of esterases, and therefore the application of the phosphoramidate approach for distributing the compound to HCV-infected hepatocytes is well aligned for the HCV phosphoramidates 5 and 6. In contrast, the in vivo distribution of the nucleoside triphosphate 1-NTP into lung tissues would presumably depend upon the rate of absorption and metabolism in lung cells compared to those in hepatocytes and other tissues. To assess the metabolism and distribution of 1 into lung cells from the central compartment, nonhuman primates were used as the model since the plasma half-life of 1 in rodents is very short (<1 min) due to abundant plasma carboxylesterases. Oral dosing of 1 in cynomolgus monkey demonstrated a low oral bioavailability (<1%) due to high intestinal and first-pass hepatic extraction of 1 (data not shown). Therefore, we dosed 1 by intravenous (IV) administration to demonstrate that 1 could (i) generate the active anabolite 1-NTP in lung tissue from exposure in the central compartment; (ii) deliver higher concentrations of 1-NTP in lungs than that of parent 4, and (iii) confer antiviral efficacy in vivo toward RSV to confirm active metabolite formation in epithelial cells that harbor replicating RSV virus. The plasma pharmacokinetics in cynomolgus and AGM following a 30 min IV dosing of 10 mg/kg of 1 and 20 mg/kg of 4 (cynomolgus only) are shown in Figure 5 and Table 5. The plasma Cmax and exposure of 1 in both AGM and cynomolgus monkey were comparable, and the plasma half-life was less than 1 h in both species consistent with the human pharmacokinetics.(56) The breakdown of prodrug 1 in the plasma and tissue also resulted in plasma exposures of parent 4 that were comparable in both species.
    Table 5. Plasma and Tissue Pharmacokinetics in Nonhuman Primates Following 30 min IV Administration

     AUCinf (μM·h)8.48.7123
    1-NTPa (nmol/g)PBMC (μM)b7.5432.28.59
     lung1.031.390.41
     lower bronchi1.120.190.17
     mainstem bronchi0.810.380.22
     trachea0.540.530.18
    all metabolitesc (nmol/g)liver17.318.42.44

    a

    1-NTP levels in PBMC and respiratory tissues (lung, bronchi, trachea) collected at 24 h following initiation of intravenous infusion, reported as nmol/g of tissues.

    b

    PBMC intracellular concentration of 1-NTP reported using a 0.2 pL/cell volume conversion.

    c

    Total nucleos(t)ide metabolite levels in liver and kidney tissues collected at 24 h represent the sum of 4, mono- and diphosphates of 4, and 1-NTP species for each tissue. Parameters: clearance (CL; L/h/kg); volume of distribution at steady state (Vss; L/kg); terminal half-life (T1/2; h); maximum concentration (Cmax; μM); and area under the concentration–time curve from time 0 to infinity (AUCinf; μM·h).

    Tissues from different parts of the lower respiratory tract, including the trachea, mainstem bronchus, lower bronchi, and lung, were collected at 24 h following dosing and analyzed for the 1-NTP content (Figure 5B). In cynomolgus monkey, the 1-NTP levels generated from prodrug 1, relative to parent 4, were several fold higher in the lung and trachea and comparable in the bronchi tissues, despite the lower dose. Normalizing the molar doses of 1 and 4 resulted in prodrug 1 delivering 1-NTP 15-fold more efficiently into the lung tissue of cynomolgus monkey than 4 and 4-fold more efficiently in the lower bronchi. An estimate of the 1-NTP lung tissue concentration at 24 h post infusion is ∼3 μM, approximately 10-fold higher than the estimated intracellular IC50 against RSV, suggesting that a 10 mg/kg daily IV infusion in nonhuman primate models of RSV has the potential to be efficacious. In AGM, the 1-NTP levels following dosing of 1 were slightly lower in the lungs leading to an estimated 11-fold improved efficiency compared to 4 (using the cynomolgus monkey data for 4) and comparable or superior in other respiratory tissues. Taken together, these data suggest that over a 24 h dosing interval, the prodrug 1 can more effectively generate 1-NTP in the lower respiratory tract tissues than 4 despite its relatively short plasma half-life and that a broad distribution of 1-NTP across different sections of the lower lung is maintained.
    Reliable methods to measure the anabolite 1-NTP levels within specific cell types of the collected lung tissues are currently unavailable and hampered by the potential for 1-NTP to decompose during sample preparation. Therefore, to indirectly demonstrate the effective loading of 1-NTP into cells where the RSV virus predominantly replicates (e.g., ciliated cells and alveolar pneumocytes), we chose to examine the effect of 1 in an AGM model of RSV. Nucleoside 3 was reported to have efficacy in this model when administered prophylactically and later also demonstrated efficacy in a human challenge treatment study confirming the translational value of this model for human RSV infection.(37) A similar experiment to that reported for 3 was conducted using IV administration of 10 mg/kg 1, initiated 4 h prior to RSV infection, with additional doses delivered daily at 24, 48, 72, 96, and 120 h post infection (Figure 6). Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) samples and nasopharyngeal swabs were collected every other day beginning at day 1 post infection until day 15. On the days when the active drug was administered, the BAL and nasal sampling were performed prior to dosing and viral loads were assessed by RT-qPCR. Relative to vehicle control, a significant drop of >2-log in BAL peak viral load was observed in the treatment animals during the dosing period. A rebound in the BAL viral load was observed in the 4–5 days following cessation of dosing, and then the virus was cleared through day 15 in both the vehicle and treatment arms at a similar rate. In the nasopharyngeal swab samples, a similar decrease in nasal viral load was observed. These results demonstrated that 1 significantly reduces RSV replication in the lung lavage samples (>99%) and the upper airway supporting the generation of 1-NTP in the ciliated and alveolar lung cells where RSV replicates.
    Intravenous dosing was a suitable delivery method of 1 for Ebola treatment in the clinic due to the gastrointestinal complications in Ebola patients and their inpatient status. For respiratory infections, a more convenient route of delivery is highly desirable, especially for treatment in the outpatient setting. In parallel to the clinical program investigating IV administration of 1 for COVID-19 treatment, research into subcutaneous injection and inhaled administration of 1 has led to the clinical development of an inhaled product. The potent anti-RSV activity of 1, together with the different formulation options, will allow for the future clinical investigation of 1 toward RSV infection and other respiratory viruses in vulnerable patient populations.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Phenotypic screening efforts toward RSV resulted in the identification of lead 4, a 1′-CN adenine C-nucleoside as a submicromolar inhibitor of RSV. SAR studies evaluating the RSV activity of alternative 1′-modifications confirmed that the 1′-CN modification was optimal for potency and selectivity toward RSV leading to a prodrug campaign aimed at improving the cell-based potency and drug-like properties of 4. The phosphoramidate prodrug 1 was discovered to have a 35-fold improved potency toward RSV in HEp-2 cells and 32- to 40-fold improved potency in NHBE and HAE cultures compared to 4, suggesting that the parent has slow and inefficient metabolism in primary human lung cells. Intracellular metabolism analyses across primary human lung cell lines established the rapid generation of high concentrations of the active anabolite 1-NTP from prodrug 1, relative to incubation with 4. In AGM and cynomolgus monkeys, despite the short plasma half-life of 1, the active 1-NTP was generated in lung tissues 11- and 15-fold more efficiently than from the administration of 4, respectively. Generation of 1-NTP in virally infected lung cells was then demonstrated indirectly in an AGM model of RSV where prophylactic IV administration of 1 resulted in the inhibition of virus replication in the lung and nasal tissues. These early data were later supported by additional animal studies demonstrating the effectiveness of IV administration of 1 in models of Nipah and coronaviruses including SARS-CoV-2 using prophylactic- and treatment-based regimens.(40−44) It has therefore been well established that phosphoramidate prodrugs can effectively produce monophosphate nucleotide metabolites within lung tissues, which can then be metabolized to the NTPs to generate antiviral responses. Prodrug 1, discovered for the respiratory pathogen RSV, and approved for the treatment of SARS-CoV-2 in hospitalized patients, illustrates the importance of continued research into nucleotide respiratory antivirals in the fight against known and emerging respiratory viruses.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    All organic compounds were synthesized at Gilead Sciences, Inc. (Foster City, CA) unless otherwise noted. Commercially available solvents and reagents were used as received without further purification. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker 300 MHz or Varian Mercury Plus 400 MHz at room temperature (rt), with tetramethylsilane as an internal standard. Proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectra are reported in parts per million (ppm) on the δ scale and are referenced from the residual protium in the NMR solvent (CHCl3-d1: δ 7.26, MeOH-d4: δ 3.31, DMSO-d6: δ 2.50, CH3CN-d3: δ 1.93). Data is reported as follows: chemical shift [multiplicity (s = singlet, d = doublet, t = triplet, q = quartet, p = pentet, sep = septet, m = multiplet, br = broad, app = apparent)], coupling constants (J) in Hertz, integration. Phosphorus-31 nuclear magnetic resonance spectra are reported in parts per million on the δ scale. Data is reported as follows: chemical shift [multiplicity (s = singlet, d = doublet, t = triplet, m = multiplet), integration. No special nomenclature is used for equivalent phosphorus resonances. LCMS (A) was conducted on a Thermo Finnigan MSQ Std. using electrospray positive and negative [M + 1]+ and [M – 1]− with a Dionex Summit HPLC System (model: P680A HPG) equipped with a Gemini 5 μ C18 110 Å column (30 mm × 4.60 mm), eluting with 0.05% formic acid in 1% CH3CN/water (Buffer A) and 0.05% formic acid in 99% CH3CN/water (Buffer B); gradient 5–100% Buffer B in Buffer A over 2.5 min and then 100% buffer B for 0.9 min at 2 mL/min. LCMS (B) was conducted on a Thermo LCQ Advantage equipped with a Phenomenex Gemini, C18, 5 μ, 110 Å column (30 mm × 4.6 mm) eluting with 0.1% acetic acid in water (Buffer A) and 0.1% acetic acid in CH3CN (Buffer B); gradient 5–100% Buffer B in Buffer A over 2.5 min and then 100% buffer B for 0.9 min at 2 mL/min. LCMS (C) was conducted on a Thermo LCQ Fleet with a Thermo Accela 1250 UHPLC equipped with a Phenomenex Kinetex 2.6 μm XB-C18 110 Å column (50 mm × 3.0 mm) eluting with 0.1% formic acid in water (Buffer A) and 0.1% formic acid in CH3CN (Buffer B); gradient 0–1.8 min 2–100% buffer B, 1.8–1.85 min 100–2% buffer B and then 1.85–2.00 min 2% CH3CN at 1.8 mL/min. Analytical thin-layer chromatography was performed using Merck KGaA Silica gel 60 F254 glass plates with UV visualization. Preparative normal phase silica gel chromatography was carried out using a Teledyne ISCO CombiFlash Companion instrument with silica gel cartridges. Purities of the final compounds were determined by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and were greater than 95% unless otherwise noted. HPLC purity was determined on an Agilent 1100 Series HPLC equipped with a Phenomenex Kinetex C18, 2.6 μm 100 Å column (100 mm × 4.6 mm) eluting with a 2–98% gradient of 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid in water and 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid in CH3CN at a flow rate of 1.5 mL/min. Preparative HPLC was conducted on a Phenomenex Synergi 4 μm Hydro-RR 80 Å column (150 mm × 30 mm) eluting with water and CH3CN.
    Compounds 1, 1-Rp, 4, 7–10, 16a–b, 17, 18a–b, 18d–g, 18i–j, and 19 have been synthesized previously.(8)

    (2R,3R,4R,5R)-5-(Acetoxymethyl)-2-(4-aminopyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-2-cyanotetrahydrofuran-3,4-diyl Diacetate (11)

    Compound 11 (36 mg, 86% yield) was prepared in a similar manner to 13 except acetic acid (29 μL, 0.50 mmol) was used instead of iso-butyric acid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CHCl3-d3) δ 11.15 (bs, 1H), 8.08 (bs, 1H), 7.97 (s, 1H), 7.35 (m, 1H), 7.12 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 1H), 6.06 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H), 5.40 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 1H), 4.67 (m, 1H), 4.48–4.32 (m, 2H), 2.20 (s, 3H), 2.17 (s, 3H), 2.09 (s, 3H). LCMS (B) m/z = 418.0 [M + H], 416.0 [M – H].

    (2R,3R,4R,5R)-2-(4-Aminopyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-2-cyano-5-((propionyloxy)methyl)tetrahydrofuran-3,4-diyl Dipropionate (12)

    Compound 12 (44 mg, 95% yield) was prepared in a similar manner as 13 except propionic acid (37 μL, 0.50 mmol) was used instead of iso-butyric acid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, MeOH-d4) δ 8.04 (s, 1H), 7.23 (d, J = 4.7 Hz, 1H), 7.03 (d, J = 4.7 Hz, 1H), 6.20 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H), 5.51 (dd, J = 5.7, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 4.67 (td, J = 4.5, 3.5 Hz, 1H), 4.49 (dd, J = 12.3, 3.6 Hz, 1H), 4.38 (dd, J = 12.3, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 2.56–2.40 (m, 4H), 2.36 (qd, J = 7.6, 5.1 Hz, 2H), 1.30–1.06 (m, 9H). LCMS (B) m/z = 460.2 [M + H].

    (2R,3R,4R,5R)-2-(4-Aminopyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-2-cyano-5-((isobutyryloxy)methyl)tetrahydrofuran-3,4-diyl Bis(2-methylpropanoate) (13)

    Compound 4 (29 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in anhydrous DMF (1 mL). Iso-butyric acid (46 μL, 0.5 mmol) was added in one portion and then N,N′-diisopropylcarbodiimide (78 μL, 0.5 mmol) was added dropwise. The reaction mixture was stirred for 15 min and then 4-(dimethylamino)pyridine (12.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred for 16 h, diluted with CH3CN (1 mL), and the solids were removed by filtration. The filtrate was subjected to preparative HPLC (0–95% CH3CN in water) to afford 13 (48 mg, 95% yield) as a white powder. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CHCl3-d3) δ 11.15 (bs, 1H), 8.27 (bs, 1H), 7.95 (s, 1H), 7.32 (m, 1H), 7.07 (m, 1H), 6.05 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 1H), 5.44 (t, J = 5.1 Hz, 1H), 4.66 (t, J = 3.6 Hz, 1H), 4.32 (m, 2H), 2.73–2.52 (m, 3H), 1.27–1.14 (m, 18H). LCMS (B) m/z = 502.2 [M + H], 500.1 [M – H].

    ((2R,3S,4R,5R)-5-(4-Aminopyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-5-cyano-3,4-dihydroxytetrahydrofuran-2-yl)methyl l-Valinate (14)

    Compound 4 (50 mg, 0.17 mmol) and (tert-butoxycarbonyl)-l-valine (55 mg, 0.56 mmol) were dissolved in anhydrous DMF (2 mL). N,N′-Diisopropylcarbodiimide (40 μL, 0.26 mmol) was added, and the mixture was stirred for 15 min followed by the addition of (2R,3R,4S,5R)-2-(4-aminopyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-3,4-dihydroxy-5-(hydroxymethyl)tetrahydrofuran-2-carbonitrile (50 mg, 0.17 mmol) and Et3N (47 μL, 0.34 mmol). The resulting mixture was stirred for 16 h and additional (tert-butoxycarbonyl)-l-valine (55 mg, 0.56 mmol) and N,N′-diisopropylcarbodiimide (40 μL, 0.25 mmol) were added. The mixture was stirred for another 5 h at rt and then heated at 50 °C for 3 h and then stirred for 72 h at rt. The mixture was diluted with EtOAc and washed with saturated NaHCO3 and saturated brine. The organic layer was dried over Na2SO4, concentrated under reduced pressure, and subjected to silica gel chromatography eluting with EtOAc in hexanes (0–70%). The resultant product was then subjected to reverse-phase HPLC. The isolated compound was dissolved in 20% TFA in CH2Cl2, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. The mixture was then concentrated under reduced pressure and subjected to preparative HPLC (0–95% CH3CN in water) to afford 14 (16 mg, 24%) in 91% purity. 1H NMR (400 MHz, MeOH-d4) δ 7.92 (s, 1H), 7.05 (s, 2H), 5.57 (dd, J = 5.8, 2.3 Hz, 1H), 5.31 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 1H), 4.49 (q, J = 3.0 Hz, 1H), 4.18–4.04 (m, 1H), 3.93–3.77 (m, 2H), 2.53 (qd, J = 7.0, 4.5 Hz, 1H), 1.16 (dd, J = 7.0, 4.9 Hz, 6H). LCMS (B) m/z = 391.2 [M + 1].

    S,S′-2,2′-((((2R,3S,4R,5R)-5-(4-Aminopyrrolo[1,2-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-5-cyano-3,4-dihydroxytetrahydrofuran-2-yl)methoxy)phosphoryl)bis(oxy)bis(ethane-2,1-diyl) Bis(2,2-dimethylpropanethioate) (15)

    Compound 4 (28 mg, 0.096 mmol) was dissolved in trimethylphosphate (1 mL). The reaction was stirred under N2 (g) and then treated with 1H-tetrazole (21 mg, 0.29 mmol). The reaction mixture was cooled to 0 °C, and phosphorane(50) (87 mg, 0.192 mmol) was added. The reaction was stirred for 2 h and then quenched with 30% hydrogen peroxide (0.120 mL). The mixture was stirred for 30 min at rt and then treated with saturated aqueous sodium thiosulfate (1 mL). The mixture was stirred for 10 min and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was subjected to preparative HPLC (0–95% CH3CN in water) to isolate 15 (5.3 mg, 8.3%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CH3CN-d3) δ 7.98 (s, 1H), 6.92 (d, 1H), 6.81 (d, 1H), 6.44 (bs, 2H), 4.82 (m, 2H), 4.47 (m, 1H), 4.24 (m, 2H), 4.00 (m, 4H), 3.80 (bs, 1H), 3.11 (m, 4H), 1.24 (s, 9H). 31P NMR (121.4 MHz, CH3CN-d3) δ -1.85 (s). LCMS (B) m/z 661 [M + H].

    Cyclopropylmethyl ((((2R,3S,4R,5R)-5-(4-Aminopyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-5-cyano-3,4-dihydroxytetrahydrofuran-2-yl)methoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate (18c)

    (S)-1-(Cyclopropylmethoxy)-1-oxopropan-2-amine hydrochloride (1.0 g, 5.57 mmol) was dried by coevaporation with CH2Cl2 and then stored under reduced pressure overnight. The aminium chloride was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (10 mL), cooled to −78 °C, and treated with phenyl dichlorophosphate (0.83 mL, 5.57 mmol). Et3N (1.54 mL, 11.13 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (1.5 mL) was added over 30 min at −78 °C. The resultant mixture was stirred for 30 min at −78 °C and then 4-nitrophenol (774 mg, 5.57 mmol) was added in one portion. Et3N (0.77 mL, 7.16 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added over 30 min at −78 °C. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min at −78 °C, washed with water, sat Na2CO3 solution, and brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was subjected to silica gel chromatography (0–20% EtOAc in hexanes) to yield cyclopropylmethyl((4-nitrophenoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate as a diastereomeric mixture (1.1 g, 47%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CHCl3-d3) δ 8.22 (m, 2H), 7.58–7.29 (m, 4H), 7.32–7.14 (m, 3H), 4.25–4.07 (m, 1H), 4.07–3.80 (m, 3H), 1.44 (d, J = 2.9 Hz, 1.5H), 1.42 (d, J = 2.9 Hz, 1.5H), 1.26–1.01 (m, 1H), 0.66–0.49 (m, 2H), 0.42–0.15 (m, 2H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CHCl3-d3) δ −3.07, −3.11. LCMS (C) m/z = 420.97 [M + 1]. A mixture of 4 (60 mg, 0.21 mmol), cyclopropylmethyl ((4-nitrophenoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate (120 mg, 0.29 mmol), and MgCl2 (29 mg, 0.31 mmol) in DMF (4 mL) was treated dropwise with N,N-diisopropylethylamine (0.09 mL, 0.52 mmol) at rt. The resulting mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 1 h, concentrated under reduced pressure to ∼2 mL, and then subjected to preparative HPLC (0–70% CH3CN in water) to afford 18c (45 mg, 38%, 1:1.9 isomeric mixture) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, MeOH-d4) δ 7.85 (m, 1H), 7.28 (m, 2H), 7.24–7.10 (m, 3H), 6.99–6.80 (m, 2H), 4.79 (m, 1H), 4.50–4.23 (m, 3H), 4.25–4.13 (m, 1H), 3.97–3.74 (m, 3H), 1.26 (m, 3H), 1.08 (m, 1H), 0.50 (m, 2H), 0.24 (m, 2H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, MeOH-d4) δ 3.74 (s, 0.67P), 3.62 (s, 0.33P). LCMS (C) m/z = 573.02 [M + 1].

    Cyclobutylmethyl ((((2R,3S,4R,5R)-5-(4-Aminopyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-5-cyano-3,4-dihydroxytetrahydrofuran-2-yl)methoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate (18h)

    A solution of dichlorophosphoryloxybenzene (300 mg, 1.42 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) under an atmosphere of argon was treated with cyclobutylmethyl l-alaninate hydrochloride (275 mg, 1.42 mmol) at −78 °C. N,N-Diisopropylethylamine (0.50 mL, 2.84 mmol) was added slowly over 5 min, and the reaction mixture was stirred for 15 min before warming to 0 °C. After 1 h, 2,3,4,5,6-pentafluorophenol (262 mg, 1.42 mmol) was added followed by N,N-diisopropylethylamine (0.25 mL, 1.42 mmol) and the mixture was stirred for 15 min. The reaction was stirred, allowed to warm to rt for 30 min, and then acidified with acetic acid (5 mL). The reaction mixture was washed with water (50 mL), dried over sodium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was subjected to silica gel chromatography (0–20% ethyl acetate in hexanes) to afford cyclobutylmethyl ((perfluorophenoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate (616 mg, 61%) as a diastereomeric mixture. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 7.45–7.38 (m, 2H), 7.31–7.19 (m, 3H), 6.99–6.89 (m, 1H), 4.05–3.95 (m, 3H), 2.00–1.68 (m, 7H), 1.33–1.27 (m, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 0.64–0.39 (m). 19F NMR (376 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ −154.02 to −154.46 (m, 3F), −160.62 to −161.05 (m, 2F), −163.39 to −163.79 (m, 3F). LCMS (C) m/z = 480.8 [M + 1]. Cyclobutylmethyl ((perfluorophenoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate (0.207 g, 0.43 mmol), 17, and magnesium chloride (0.043 g, 0.45 mmol) were combined in acetonitrile (5 mL) and heated in a sealed vessel at 50 °C for 15 min. N,N-Diisopropylethylamine (0.20 mL, 1.13 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was heated for 2 h. The mixture was allowed to cool and then diluted with EtOAc (10 mL). The organic layer was washed with water, brine, dried over sodium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was dissolved in a 2:1 mixture of THF and conc. HCl (10 mL) and stirred for 4 h. The reaction mixture was neutralized with a saturated aq. solution of sodium bicarbonate and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was subjected to silica gel chromatography eluting with 0–60% MeOH in CH2Cl2 to afford 18h (95 mg, 42% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, MeOH-d4) δ 7.86–7.84 (m, 1H), 7.32–7.25 (m, 2H), 7.20–7.11 (m, 3H), 6.92–6.86 (m, 2H), 4.79 (d, J = 5.5 Hz, 1H), 4.45–4.34 (m, 2H), 4.33–4.26 (m, 1H), 4.22–4.16 (m, 1H), 4.08–3.93 (m, 2H), 3.91–3.79 (m, 1H), 2.63–2.53 (m, 1H), 2.08–1.68 (m, 6H), 1.32–1.22 (m, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, MeOH-d4) δ 3.74–3.70 (m, 0.67P), 3.65–3.61 (m, 0.33P). LCMS (C) m/z = 587.3 [M + 1].

    Cyclooctyl ((((2R,3S,4R,5R)-5-(4-Aminopyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-5-cyano-3,4-dihydroxytetrahydrofuran-2-yl)methoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate (18k)

    A solution of cyclooctyl l-alaninate hydrochloride (18.69 g, 79.28 mmol) and phenyl dichlorophosphate (11.8 mL, 79.28 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (300 mL) was treated with Et3N (23 mL, 166.48 mmol) at 0 °C under N2 (g). After 5 min, 4-nitrophenol (10.48 g, 75.31 mmol) and Et3N (11.5 mL, 79.28 mmol) were added and the stirred mixture was allowed to warm to rt. After 1 h, the reaction mixture was diluted with Et2O and the solids were collected by filtration and washed with Et2O. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure, and the crude residue was subjected to silica gel column chromatography (0–20% MeOH in CH2Cl2) to afford cyclooctyl((4-nitrophenoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate (25.8 g, 68%) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CH3CN-d3) δ 8.26 (dd, J = 9.1, 1.7 Hz, 2H), 7.49–7.35 (m, 4H), 7.34–7.18 (m, 3H), 4.95–4.81 (m, 1H), 4.66 (ddd, J = 12.7, 10.1, 7.2 Hz, 1H), 4.10–3.96 (m, 1H), 1.79–1.43 (m, 14H), 1.31 (dd, J = 7.1, 4.5 Hz, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CH3CN-d3) δ −2.07, −2.21. LCMS (C) m/z = 476.69 [M + H]. A mixture of 17 (0.50 g, 1.51 mmol) and cyclooctyl((4-nitrophenoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate (0.83 g, 1.74 mmol) in anhydrous THF (8 mL) was treated with magnesium chloride (0.58 g, 6.04 mmol) and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (0.78 g, 6.04 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 3 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was diluted with CH2Cl2, washed with saturated sodium chloride solution, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was subjected to silica gel column chromatography (0–20% of (50% MeOH in CH2Cl2) in CH2Cl2) to afford cyclooctyl ((((3aR,4R,6R,6aR)-6-(4-aminopyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-6-cyano-2,2-dimethyltetrahydrofuro[3,4-d][1,3]dioxol-4-yl)methoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate (0.823 g, 81%) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CH3CN-d3) δ 7.93 (d, J = 1.9 Hz, 1H), 7.31 (q, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.21–7.00 (m, 3H), 6.90 (dd, J = 6.3, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 6.79 (dd, J = 7.5, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 6.46 (s, 2H), 5.32 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 1H), 5.14 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 1H), 5.00–4.77 (m, 2H), 4.60 (dd, J = 16.2, 4.1 Hz, 1H), 4.36–4.17 (m, 2H), 3.90–3.61 (m, 1H), 1.70 (t, J = 4.7 Hz, 8H), 1.58–1.42 (m, 6H), 1.39 (d, J = 11.1 Hz, 6H), 1.22 (ddd, J = 12.5, 7.1, 1.0 Hz, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CH3CN-d3) δ 2.97, 2.78. LCMS (C) m/z = 669.06 [M + H]. The mixture of cyclooctyl ((((3aR,4R,6R,6aR)-6-(4-aminopyrrolo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazin-7-yl)-6-cyano-2,2-dimethyltetrahydrofuro[3,4-d][1,3]dioxol-4-yl)methoxy)(phenoxy)phosphoryl)-l-alaninate (0.82 g, 1.23 mmol) in CH3CN (10 mL) at 0 °C was treated with conc. HCl (0.7 mL, 19.2 mmol) and stirred at rt for 1 h. The mixture was cooled in an ice bath and then diluted with water before neutralization by the addition of 2 N NaOH. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (2 × 20 mL), and the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was subjected to preparative HPLC (15–85% CH3CN in water) to afford an ∼1:1 diastereomeric mixture of 18k (0.59 g, 76%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 7.90 (d, J = 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.31 (q, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.21–7.06 (m, 3H), 6.92–6.74 (m, 2H), 6.27 (dd, J = 11.6, 6.1 Hz, 1H), 5.94 (dt, J = 13.0, 9.7 Hz, 1H), 5.34 (dd, J = 7.9, 5.7 Hz, 1H), 4.74 (dd, J = 8.0, 4.2 Hz, 1H), 4.67–4.57 (m, 1H), 4.31–4.18 (m, 2H), 4.17–4.00 (m, 1H), 3.93 (dd, J = 10.7, 5.3 Hz, 1H), 3.78–3.59 (m, 1H), 1.77–1.28 (m, 14H), 1.14 (dd, J = 19.5, 7.1 Hz, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 3.83 (s, 0.5P), 3.80 (s, 0.5P). LCMS (C) m/z = 628.97 [M + H].

    Cell Lines for Antiviral Assays and HCV 1b Replicon Assay

    See the Supporting Information.

    RSV A2 HEp-2 Antiviral and Cytotoxicity Assay

    Compounds were 3-fold serially diluted in source plates from which 100 nL of the diluted compound was transferred to a 384-well cell culture plate using an Echo acoustic transfer apparatus. HEp-2 cells at a density of 5 × 104 cells/mL were then infected by adding RSV A2 at a titer of 1 × 104 tissue culture infectious doses (TCID50)/mL. Immediately following virus addition, 20 μL of the virus/cell mixture was added to the 384-well cell culture plates using a μFlow liquid dispenser and cultured for 4 days at 37 °C. After incubation, the cells were allowed to equilibrate to 25 °C for 30 min. The RSV-induced cytopathic effect was determined by adding 20 μL of a CellTiter Glo viability reagent. After a 10 min incubation at 25 °C, cell viability was determined by measuring luminescence using an Envision plate reader. For the cytotoxicity assessment, HEp-2 (1.5 × 103 cells/well) were plated in 384-well plates and incubated with the appropriate medium containing a 3-fold serially diluted compound ranging from 15 to 100 000 nM. Cells were cultured for 4–5 days at 37 °C. Following the incubation, the cells were allowed to equilibrate to 25 °C, and cell viability was determined by adding a CellTiter Glo viability reagent. The mixture was incubated for 10 min, and the luminescence signal was quantified using an Envision plate reader.

    MT-4 Cytotoxicity Assay

    Test compounds were serially diluted in 1:3 increments (total 10 concentrations) in DMSO in quadruplicate and acoustically transferred into 384-well black assay plates. The top concentration is usually 10 or 20 mM in DMSO, which works out to 50 or 100 μM, respectively, in this assay format. A 10 μM puromycin-positive control was added to the last column of each assay plate as a positive control for cytotoxicity. MT-4 cells (3 × 103 cells/well) were added to each plate containing the test compound using a Viaflo 384-well pipetter. After 5 days in a humidified and temperature-controlled incubator (37 °C, 5% CO2), CellTiter Glo (Promega) was added to the assay plates with the Viaflo and mixed thoroughly, and chemiluminescent signals from each plate were read using an Envision plate reader. CC50 values were defined as the compound concentration that causes a 50% decrease in luminescence signal and calculated using a sigmoidal dose–response model to generate fitted curves.

    RSV RNP Complex Assay and HCV RdRp Biochemical Assay

    See ref (7) for RSV RNP assay and ref (31) for the HCV RdRp assay methods.

    RSV NHBE Assay

    Cells (5.0 × 103/well) were seeded in white wall/clear bottom 96-well plates (Corning) with culture medium to a final volume of 100 μL and incubated for 24 h at 37 °C with 5% CO2. On the following day, 3-fold serial dilutions (starting at 9.28 nM and ending at 2000 nM) of 1 or 4 prepared in DMSO were added to the wells using the HP D300e digital dispenser with normalization to the highest concentration of DMSO in all wells (>0.1% final volume). The cells were then infected with RSV-Fluc diluted with BEGM media at an MOI of 0.1 for a final volume of 200 μL media/well. Uninfected and untreated wells were included as controls to determine compound efficacy against RSV-Fluc. Following incubation with the compound and virus for 3 days at 37 °C with 5% CO2, 100 μL of culture supernatant was removed from each well and replaced with 100 μL of ONE-Glo luciferase reagent (Promega, Madison, WI, Cat# E6110). The plates were gently mixed by rocking for 10 min at rt, and luminescence signal was measured using an Envision plate reader (PerkinElmer). Values were normalized to the uninfected and infected DMSO controls (0 and 100% infection, respectively). Data was fit using nonlinear regression analysis using XLfit4. EC50 values were then determined as the concentration reducing the firefly luciferase signal by 50%. The compiled data was generated based on the least two independent experimental replicates, each containing technical duplicates for each concentration.

    RSV HAE Assay

    Human airway epithelial (HAE) cells (donor # 33660E) were sourced from MatTek Corporation (Ashland, MA). Differentiated HAE cultures were maintained as per the manufacturer’s instruction until the day of infection and treatment. On day 0, cells were washed twice with 1× DPBS (ThermoFisher Scientific). All compounds were diluted in DMSO to a 1 μM working concentration. 1 and 1-Rp were further diluted in the assay media (MatTek) to the final concentrations of 0.25, 0.05, and 0.01 μM, while 4 was diluted in the assay media to the final concentrations of 10, 1.25, and 0.25 μM. Two milliliters/well of the compound at the indicated concentration was added to the basolateral side of the transwell HAE culture. Cells were then infected apically with RSV A2 WT virus diluted in the assay media at an MOI of 0.1 to a final volume of 200 μL/well. Cells were incubated with the virus at 37 °C with 5% CO2 for 3 h. Untreated wells were included as controls. The virus was aspirated from the wells, and cells were further incubated for 24 h at 37 °C with 5% CO2. Each subsequent day for 2 days, DPBS was added apically to the cells at a final volume of 200 μL/well. Cells were incubated for 30 min at 37 °C with 5% CO2. DPBS was aspirated from the wells, and treatment was continuously administered on days 1 and 2 by adding 2 mL/well of freshly diluted compounds (same concentration as before) to the basolateral side of the transwell HAE culture. Cells were returned to the incubator at 37 °C. On day 3, 200 μL of the DPBS was added apically to each well and the cells were incubated for 30 min at 37 °C with 5% CO2. Hundred microliters/well of the apical wash was harvested into 200 μL of lysis buffer (ThermoFisher Scientific). Xenotropic RNA (Vetmax Xeno) internal positive control (ThermoFisher Scientific) was included in the lysis buffer as a control for RNA isolation. Viral RNA was extracted from the collected samples using the MagMAx-96 Viral RNA isolation kit (ThermoFisher Scientific) and Kingfisher Flex instrument (ThermoFisher Scientific) as per the manufacturer’s instruction. Viral loads in HAE cultures were determined by RT-qPCR assay as below. Quantitative RT-PCR was performed using the TaqMan RNA-to-CT 1-Step kit (ThermoFisher Scientific). Briefly, 5 μL of the extracted viral RNA was mixed with 10 μL of the buffer from the kit, 0.5 μL of the RT enzyme, the appropriate primer/probe for either RSV N or the xenotropic RNA, and RT-PCR grade water (ThermoFisher Scientific) to a final volume of 20 μL. For the RSV-specific reactions, 0.5 μL of 40× RSV N Primer Probe (Integrated DNA Technology PrimeTime qPCR Assay XL; forward primer: 5′ GCTAGTGTGCAAGCAGAAATG 3′, reverse primer: 5′ TGGAGAAGTGAGGAAATT GAGTC 3′, and probe: 5′ FAM/ATTGGGTGG/ZEN/AGAAGCAGGGTTCTAC/3IABkFQ 3′ (Coralville, Iowa)) was added per reaction. For the 20× Vetmax Xeno Internal Positive Control-VIC Assay (ThermoFisher Scientific), 0.8 μL of the primer/probe set was added. Each reaction was performed in duplicate. PCR plates were sealed with a MicroAmp optical adhesive film (ThermoFisher Scientific) and centrifuged for 1 min at 1200 RPM. The one-step PCR reaction and subsequent amplification analysis were carried out using the QuantStudio 12K Flex Real Time PCR system using the following conditions: 48 °C for 15 min, 95 °C for 10 min, followed by 40 cycles of qPCR for 15 s at 95 °C and at 60 °C for 1 min. Reactions containing 10-fold serial dilutions of RSV A2 N gene with a pTM1 backbone solution were used to generate a standard curve against which the RSV RNA content measured from test samples was quantified. Median and interquartile ranges (IQR) of six technical replicates were determined for each treatment. The p values were determined by the Mann–Whitney Student t test (unpaired nonparametric).

    Log D Measurement, Caco-2 Assay, and In Vitro 1-NTP Metabolism Methods

    See the Supporting Information.

    In Vivo Methods

    In vivo pharmacokinetic (PK) studies were performed at Charles River Laboratories (rat and dog; Worcester, MA), Covance (cynomolgus monkey; Madison, Wisconsin), and Lovelace Biomedical Research Institute (AGM; Albuquerque, NM) in accordance with local IACUC guidelines and the AGM RSV efficacy study at Bioqual, Inc. (Rockville, MD) under local IACUC guidelines. For nonterminal studies, compound 4 was formulated in 5% EtOH, 30% propylene glycol (PG), 45% PEG 400, and 20% water + 1 equiv of HCl at 0.50 mg/mL for IV infusion and at 2.50 mg/mL for oral dosing. Each dosing group consisted of three male Sprague–Dawley rats, or three male beagle dogs (∼11.5 kg) or three male cynomolgus monkeys (3.5–6.5 kg), or three male AGM. The animals were fasted overnight prior to dose administration and up to 4 h after dosing. For the IV infusion group, the test article was administered by intravenous infusion over 30 min. The rate of infusion was adjusted according to the body weight of each animal to deliver a dose of 1 mg/kg. For the oral dosing group, the test article was administered by oral gavage at 2 mL/kg for a dose of 5 mg/kg. For the terminal tissue collection study of 4 in three male cynomolgus monkeys, 4 was formulated in 5% ethanol, 30% propylene glycol, 45% PEG 300, and 20% water (pH 2.5) and administered by a constant rate intravenous infusion over 30 minutes at 2 mL/kg for a dose of 20 mg/kg. Compound 1 was formulated in 12% sulfobutylether-β-cyclodextrin in water (pH 3.5) and administered by a constant rate intravenous infusion over 30 minutes at 2 mL/kg for a dose of 10 mg/kg in both cynomolgus monkey and AGM. Cynomolgus monkeys were two males and one female, and AGM were three males. Serial blood samples were collected in K2EDTA tubes at each time point and kept on ice until centrifuged. Immediately after centrifugation (5000 g for 10 min at 2–4 °C), the plasma was transferred into clean collection tubes and stored at −80 °C. A liquid chromatography coupled to the triple quadrupole mass spectrometry (LCMS/MS) method was used to measure the concentration of 1 and 4 in plasma similar to methods described previously.(7) Pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters were determined following a noncompartmental analysis of the plasma concentration–time data. The following PK parameters are reported: clearance (CL; L/h/kg), volume of distribution at steady state (Vss; L/kg), terminal half-life (T1/2; h), maximum concentration (Cmax; μM), and area under the concentration–time curve from time 0 to infinity (AUCinf; μM·h).
    A compound 13 mono TFA salt was formulated in 2.5% DMSO, 10% Kolliphor HS-15, 10% labrasol, 2.5% PG, and 75% water at 4 mL/kg for a targeted oral dose of 8 mg/kg 13 as its free base in rats. In cynomolgus monkey, compound 13 as its free base was formulated in 10% EtOH, 40% Kolliphor HS-15, 40% labrasol, and 10% PG at 1 mL/kg for a targeted dose of 20 mg/kg 13 in monkeys. The compound was dosed by oral gavage to three male Sprague–Dawley rats or three male cynomolgus monkeys (3.5–6.5 kg). The animals were fasted overnight prior to dose administration and up to 4 h after dosing. The in vivo dose administration and sample collection procedure remained the same as described above. An LCMS/MS method as described above was used to measure the concentration of 4 in plasma; PK parameters were derived following noncompartmental analysis of the plasma concentration–time data.
    Cynomolgus monkey and AGM respiratory and other tissues were collected as a nonsurvival surgical procedure at 24 h following the initiation of IV infusion. Animals were sedated with ketamine (10 mg/kg) administered via an intramuscular injection prior to surgery. Sections of the upper trachea, lower trachea, the mainstem bronchus (right), and lower bronchus (right) were dissected and immediately placed into liquid nitrogen, all <5 min from the start of surgery, followed by the successive collection of liver and kidney sections in the same fashion. Frozen tissues were pulverized using a cell crusher and transferred into preweighed 15 mL conical tubes, all performed and maintained on dry ice. Tissue weights were obtained by subtracting the tube weight, and a 4-fold volume of dry ice-cold extraction buffer (70% methanol containing 0.1% KOH, 67 mM EDTA, and 250 nM chloro-ATP as internal standard) was added. Standard curves were generated by spiking an appropriate amount of 4, monophosphate metabolite of 4, diphosphate metabolite of 4, and 1-NTP solution, prepared in water, into blank tissues. The mixture was then promptly homogenized using an Omni Tip tissue homogenizer with a disposable hard-tissue homogenizer probe (Omni International). A 200 μL aliquot of the homogenate was filtered using a 96-well filter plate (0.2 μm polypropylene, Agilent Captiva). The filtrate was evaporated to dryness and reconstituted with 200 μL of 1 mM ammonium phosphate buffer (pH 7) for analysis by LCMS/MS. Analysis was performed using similar methods as previously described.(7) Undosed control tissues from the lung, liver, and kidney were used for quantification of the metabolites in the respiratory tissue, liver, and kidney, respectively.

    RSV AGM Efficacy

    Eight AGMs were included in the study (randomized 1:1), and each was challenged with 2 mL of the diluted RSV A2 WT inoculum (2 × 105 PFU total) on day 0 of the study. A viral inoculum (0.5 mL) was administered dropwise into each nostril (NP-053) and 1.0 mL was delivered intratracheally using a French rubber catheter/feeding tube, size 10, sterile (cut 4″–6″ in length). Starting 4 h prior to RSV challenge, each animal received either 1 (10 mg/kg, formulated in 12% captisol in water, pH 5) or placebo to match administered by IV (1 mL/kg) infusion over 30 min. Subsequent doses of 1 and placebo were administered at 24, 48, 72, 96, and 120 h post challenge. BAL samples were collected on study days −2, +1, +3, +5, +7, +9, +11, 13, and +15 from each monkey by instilling ∼2 mL/kg of warm sterile saline and gently suctioned back before freezing. Nasopharyngeal (NP) swabs were collected on study days −2, +1, +3, +5, +7, +9, +11, 13, and +15 from each monkey with sterile cotton swabs moistened in sterile saline. Each cotton swab was placed in a tube containing 1 mL of sterile saline and immediately frozen. Samples were collected prior to dosing of 1 or placebo. To reduce stress, an intramuscular injection of ketamine HCl (10–25 mg/kg) or other appropriate anesthetics was used prior to the procedures. Viral assessment was performed by quantitative RT-PCR as described in the Supporting Information.

    Abbreviations Used
    AB

    apical to basolateral

    AGM

    African Green monkey

    ATP

    adenosine triphosphate

    BA

    basolateral to apical

    BAL

    bronchoalveolar lavage

    BEGM

    bronchial epithelial cell growth medium

    BOC

    tert-butyloxycarbonyl

    CC50

    concentration for 50% cell viability loss

    DIC

    N,N′-diisopropylcarbodiimide

    DMAP

    dimethylaminopyridine

    EDTA

    ethylenediaminetetra acetic acid

    HAE

    human airway epithelial

    HCV

    hepatitis C virus

    IACUC

    International Animal Care and Use Committee

    IV

    intravenous

    LOQ

    limit of quantification

    MERS

    Middle East respiratory syndrome

    MOI

    multiplicity of infection

    NHBE

    normal human bronchial epithelial

    NP

    nasopharyngeal

    NTP

    nucleotide triphosphate

    PBMC

    peripheral blood mononuclear cells

    PEG

    poly(ethyleneglycol)

    RdRp

    RNA-dependent RNA polymerase

    RNP

    ribonucleoprotein

    RSV

    respiratory syncytial virus

    SARS

    severe acute respiratory syndrome

    SI

    selectivity index

    TCID

    tissue culture infectious dose

    WHO

    World Health Organization

    WT

    wild type

    1. 1
      Moriyama, M.; Hugentobler, W. J.; Iwasaki, A. Seasonality of respiratory viral infections. Annu. Rev. Virol. 2020, 7, 83– 101,  DOI: 10.1146/annurev-virology-012420-022445
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Seasonality of Respiratory Viral Infections
      Moriyama, Miyu; Hugentobler, Walter J.; Iwasaki, Akiko
      Annual Review of Virology (2020), 7 (), 83-101CODEN: ARVNBS; ISSN:2327-0578. (Annual Reviews)
      A review. The seasonal cycle of respiratory viral diseases has been widely recognized for thousands of years, as annual epidemics of the common cold and influenza disease hit the human population like clockwork in the winter season in temperate regions. Moreover, epidemics caused by viruses such as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and the newly emerging SARS-CoV-2 occur during the winter months. The mechanisms underlying the seasonal nature of respiratory viral infections have been examd. and debated for many years. The two major contributing factors are the changes in environmental parameters and human behavior. Studies have revealed the effect of temp. and humidity on respiratory virus stability and transmission rates. More recent research highlights the importance of the environmental factors, esp. temp. and humidity, in modulating host intrinsic, innate, and adaptive immune responses to viral infections in the respiratory tract. Here we review evidence of how outdoor and indoor climates are linked to the seasonality of viral respiratory infections. We further discuss determinants of host response in the seasonality of respiratory viruses by highlighting recent studies in the field.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXltlCqur8%253D&md5=3e4813504d05bf837b7a84c0f4baf64f
    2. 2
      Yusuf, S.; Piedimonte, G.; Auais, A.; Demmler, G.; Krishnan, S.; Van Caeseele, P.; Singleton, R.; Broor, S.; Parveen, S.; Avendano, L.; Parra, J.; Chavez-Bueno, S.; Murguía De Sierra, T.; Simoes, E. A. F.; Shaha, S.; Welliver, R., Sr. The relationship of meteorological conditions to the epidemic activity of respiratory syncytial virus. Epidemiol. Infect. 2007, 135, 1077– 1090,  DOI: 10.1017/S095026880600776X
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      The relationship of meteorological conditions to the epidemic activity of respiratory syncytial virus
      Yusuf S; Piedimonte G; Auais A; Demmler G; Krishnan S; Van Caeseele P; Singleton R; Broor S; Parveen S; Avendano L; Parra J; Chavez-Bueno S; Murguia De Sierra T; Simoes E A F; Shaha S; Welliver R
      Epidemiology and infection (2007), 135 (7), 1077-90 ISSN:0950-2688.
      Our aim was to obtain knowledge of how meteorological conditions affect community epidemics of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection. To this end we recorded year-round RSV activity in nine cities that differ markedly in geographic location and climate. We correlated local weather conditions with weekly or monthly RSV cases. We reviewed similar reports from other areas varying in climate. Weekly RSV activity was related to temperature in a bimodal fashion, with peaks of activity at temperatures above 24-30 degrees C and at 2-6 degrees C. RSV activity was also greatest at 45-65% relative humidity. RSV activity was inversely related to UVB radiance at three sites where this could be tested. At sites with persistently warm temperatures and high humidity, RSV activity was continuous throughout the year, peaking in summer and early autumn. In temperate climates, RSV activity was maximal during winter, correlating with lower temperatures. In areas where temperatures remained colder throughout the year, RSV activity again became nearly continuous. Community activity of RSV is substantial when both ambient temperatures and absolute humidity are very high, perhaps reflecting greater stability of RSV in aerosols. Transmission of RSV in cooler climates is inversely related to temperature possibly as a result of increased stability of the virus in secretions in the colder environment. UVB radiation may inactivate virus in the environment, or influence susceptibility to RSV by altering host resistance.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Warren, T. K.; Jordan, R.; Lo, M. K.; Ray, A. S.; Mackman, R. L.; Soloveva, V.; Siegel, D.; Perron, M.; Bannister, R.; Hui, H. C.; Larson, N.; Strickley, R.; Wells, J.; Stuthman, K. Therapeutic efficacy of the small molecule GS-5734 against Ebola virus in rhesus monkeys. Nature 2016, 531, 381– 385,  DOI: 10.1038/nature17180

      7
      Therapeutic efficacy of the small molecule GS-5734 against Ebola virus in rhesus monkeys
      Warren, Travis K.; Jordan, Robert; Lo, Michael K.; Ray, Adrian S.; Mackman, Richard L.; Soloveva, Veronica; Siegel, Dustin; Perron, Michel; Bannister, Roy; Hui, Hon C.; Larson, Nate; Strickley, Robert; Wells, Jay; Stuthman, Kelly S.; Van Tongeren, Sean A.; Garza, Nicole L.; Donnelly, Ginger; Shurtleff, Amy C.; Retterer, Cary J.; Gharaibeh, Dima; Zamani, Rouzbeh; Kenny, Tara; Eaton, Brett P.; Grimes, Elizabeth; Welch, Lisa S.; Gomba, Laura; Wilhelmsen, Catherine L.; Nichols, Donald K.; Nuss, Jonathan E.; Nagle, Elyse R.; Kugelman, Jeffrey R.; Palacios, Gustavo; Doerffler, Edward; Neville, Sean; Carra, Ernest; Clarke, Michael O.; Zhang, Lijun; Lew, Willard; Ross, Bruce; Wang, Queenie; Chun, Kwon; Wolfe, Lydia; Babusis, Darius; Park, Yeojin; Stray, Kirsten M.; Trancheva, Iva; Feng, Joy Y.; Barauskas, Ona; Xu, Yili; Wong, Pamela; Braun, Molly R.; Flint, Mike; McMullan, Laura K.; Chen, Shan-Shan; Fearns, Rachel; Swaminathan, Swami; Mayers, Douglas L.; Spiropoulou, Christina F.; Lee, William A.; Nichol, Stuart T.; Cihlar, Tomas; Bavari, Sina
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2016), 531 (7594), 381-385CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The most recent Ebola virus outbreak in West Africa, which was unprecedented in the no. of cases and fatalities, geog. distribution, and no. of nations affected, highlights the need for safe, effective, and readily available antiviral agents for treatment and prevention of acute Ebola virus (EBOV) disease (EVD) or sequelae. No antiviral therapeutics have yet received regulatory approval or demonstrated clin. efficacy. Here we report the discovery of a novel small mol. GS-5734, a monophosphoramidate prodrug of an adenosine analog, with antiviral activity against EBOV. GS-5734 exhibits antiviral activity against multiple variants of EBOV and other filoviruses in cell-based assays. The pharmacol. active nucleoside triphosphate (NTP) is efficiently formed in multiple human cell types incubated with GS-5734 in vitro, and the NTP acts as an alternative substrate and RNA-chain terminator in primer-extension assays using a surrogate respiratory syncytial virus RNA polymerase. I.v. administration of GS-5734 to nonhuman primates resulted in persistent NTP levels in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (half-life, 14 h) and distribution to sanctuary sites for viral replication including testes, eyes, and brain. In a rhesus monkey model of EVD, once-daily i.v. administration of 10 mg kg-1 GS-5734 for 12 days resulted in profound suppression of EBOV replication and protected 100% of EBOV-infected animals against lethal disease, ameliorating clin. disease signs and pathophysiol. markers, even when treatments were initiated three days after virus exposure when systemic viral RNA was detected in two out of six treated animals. These results show the first substantive post-exposure protection by a small-mol. antiviral compd. against EBOV in nonhuman primates. The broad-spectrum antiviral activity of GS-5734 in vitro against other pathogenic RNA viruses, including filoviruses, arenaviruses, and coronaviruses, suggests the potential for wider medical use. GS-5734 is amenable to large-scale manufg., and clin. studies investigating the drug safety and pharmacokinetics are ongoing.

      Siegel, D.; Hui, H. C.; Doerffler, E.; Clarke, M. O.; Chun, K.; Zhang, L.; Neville, S.; Carra, E.; Lew, W.; Ross, B.; Wang, Q.; Wolfe, L.; Jordan, R.; Soloveva, V.; Knox, J.; Perry, J.; Perron, M.; Stray, K. M.; Barauskas, O.; Feng, J. Y.; Xu, Y.; Lee, G.; Rheingold, A. L.; Ray, A. S.; Bannister, B.; Strickley, R.; Swaminathan, S.; Lee, W. A.; Bavari, S.; Cihlar, T.; Lo, M. K.; Warren, T. K.; Mackman, R. L. Discovery and synthesis of a phosphoramidate prodrug of a pyrrolo[2,1-f][triazin-4-amino] adenine C-nucleoside (GS-5734) for the treatment of Ebola and emerging viruses. J. Med. Chem. 2017, 60, 1648– 1661,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.6b01594
